Down To One is a military survival game where 42 players battle it to become the final person alive.

This game is a massive disappointment. I wanted to like this game a lot and without a doubt for a dollar this game is not bad, but it's plagued by so many problems I can't recommend it.

The massive problem with this game is no one plays it. Now I only tried this game twice and once I waited an hour for a game and got nothing and then a second time I waited another hour and played a game which ended in 4 minutes.

I had a fun time even though it lasted for that short, but the fact is I didn't want to wait another hour to play another game so it could end in 5 minutes.

The game also has a lot of glitches and bugs which could easily be ironed out by the devs.

Texture popping, character models glitching, items clipping through items are just some of the issues that plague this game.

I really want to say more about this title, but sadly I can't say a lot. My honest suggestion is either find a community to play with or play with friends otherwise skip this title.

Final Rating:
3/10 - Don't Bother

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is already VERY playable and VERY fun, but listen closely.

The playerbase is extremely lacking right now.  To make up for it, every day, the Dev announces games on twitter.  Plenty of people show up and we have a great time.  The game gets an update (almost) every night.  If you want to support the development of the game, and don't mind the current playerbase issues, then this is a great investment for you.  You rarely see a person care this much about a game they are creating.  If you can convince a few friends to pick it up, it'll never be hard for you to find a game.

The playerbase issue will work itself out as more and more people pick up this gem.

Now, about the game itself:

You're in a desert of sorts, with various types of buildings strewn throughout.  You and however many people are joining the game enter via a lobby, and until everyone readies up, you can play some soccer or run around punching people and making e-motes.  Once everyone readies, the game begins.  Depending on the type of server you're in, you will all run from the center (ala Hunger Games), or be randomly spawned around the map.  Your fight for survival begins.

You go about scavenging what you can - Food, Water, Guns, Melee Weapons, Bandages, and other goodies.  You try to stay away from the poisonous snakes that prevent people from camping out in the rocky hills.  You keep an eye out for the air drop, that happens once a game and drops a crate with a decent weapon.  The weapons all have different attributes, and the hit boxes are actually where the should be.  If you swing an axe at someone, it hits where it hits.  Not in a magical line in front of you.  Bullet drop is a factor.  You will have to develop a certain level of skill.

Even though it seems like each game is only within itself, there is a degree of on-going customization and personalization via the character screen.  The longer you survive in a match, the more money you earn to put towards perks and other goodies that follow your character through all games.  And the perks aren't boring, in fact, the perks you choose can vastly effect the way you try to survive in a match.

Even in early access, it plays extremely well.  The servers seem to work fine, the mechanics are great, and the developer is very open about what needs to be worked on.  He's in constant contact with the community, and he really listens to suggestions.  All of which leads me to believe that this game is going to be a success.

Through trickery, stealth, or out-right brute force you must survive longer than every other player.  Do you make temporary allies?  How long can you trust them?

Because in the end, it comes Down To One.

10/10.  In my opinion, you should definitely pick up this title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to like this game. The idea of an extended survival deathmatch has been on my mind since Battle Royale/Hunger Games. I bought 'Down To One' over a month ago, and to this day the servers are still empty. All hours of the day (morning, afternoon, evening, past midnight!), the servers have either 1 or 0/42 players. I haven't yet been able to play the game so I can't pass judgement on the multiplayer. But from what I experienced in the practice server (only 1 person required to start): the audio sounds are weak and low-quality,  the environment looks like it was clumsily thrown together with cheap Unity assets and thoughtless lighting, the collision is terrible (floating pickups everywhere, can't reliably climb ladders), the theme/worldbuilding/writing is non-existent (there's no explanation at all for why a bunch of militants have gathered in the middle of a desert to shoot modern-day firearms at each other).

I did enjoy the nifty IK animation they put in when you pick up an item (your character's hand extend towards the item). I also liked the way they handled the UI for items (you press a # key to select an item in your inventory, then press keys to either drop it or use it).

The survival game idea is definitely cool, and definitely a trending genre in PC games right now, but the execution is TERRIBLE. 'Down To One' in its current iteration isn't even playable. I don't know what the future is like for these guys, but best of luck to you. Hope you finish your project.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The wait time to get in a game is pretty annoying at the moment, and the player animations are really.... funky. Other than that, the concept and the gameplay itself is actually really good and fun. Players spawn in and spread out scavenging buildings and watch-towers for weapons and food and water. Yes you must feed and water yourself to stay alive as well as watch out for the other players. Once you're out... you're out and the game continues to last man standing. I found it pretty hard to find a ranged weapon at first until I came across a small military base. I picked up a gun very similar to an awp from CS and began lurking in the tops of the mountains killing other players. My first game lasted about 30 min but it wasn't slow paced at all. We had a total of 20 something people in the game and at the begining, people seem to die fast from not watching their backs and getting melee'd in the back. I would say that probably 10 min in we had less than what we started with. Now once it came down to me and the last guy, it became quite boring. I'm not sure if he was just camping or we were walking circles around eachother but it took quite a while before i finally snuck up on him and picked him off with a headshot from behind. All in all it was quite fun and I played a few more games. There definitley needs to be some updates and changes especially to the player animations and the scopes on weapons. There are updates being made and the Devs seem to be answering most the questions in the forums and taking suggestions. We all love to see that with Early Access Games. I definitley recommend trying this out eventually. You might want to wait for a few more updates and hopefully the player base will jump up as well, and possibly a sale before buying it. Like I said before, the waiting times can take a while to just get a game going sometimes.
7/10 Will lurk again

Early Access Review

Okay.  What started off with a negative review has changed quickly tonight.

Yes, the animations are pretty darn horrid and could use some work...

Yes, my suspicions before this launch were right on... that waiting for 42 player games in an indie game like this would be like dating a nun and waiting for her to 'put out'.

Yes, the game has bugs and graphical glitches.

But you know what?  In less then 8 hours since it officially launched as an early access game, I've seen 4 patches now.  Who patches their early access game 4 times in the first 8 hours?!??  ..A dev team on top of trying to make their game better, that's who!  And yes it is improving already, so a big thumbs up to the team behind this game!

And here's the thing...  Despite the longer waiting times then I'd like to see to start a match, and besides the glitches and slow and awkward animations, somehow this game is still FUN!  It has me wanting to play it again and again and even accept waiting and watching all the men dance crouched and try to climb invisible walls as they also await the upcoming battle royale!

Shrugs.  I like it.  I have faith that it will get better and better.

Have a look at my 2nd game of 'Down To One'   (My video recording software didnt record any voice or game sound so I just added music) :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q1K0gDOOQg4

Bottm line, if you expect a bug-free battle royale type game, look elsewhere, but if you like the concept of this game and want to join in and support these developers and this game, then the price for admission is pretty cheap and there is fun to be had here.  I'm happy with my purchase after giving it a second chance tonight!   :-)

I'm still not sure what had happened to me. For years I had simply been SWAT unit, tackling down the most dangerous criminals and hostile organisations to keep my city safe. Now, I had suddenly woken up in the middle east, along with a lot of other SWAT men.

We found little comfort in the small stone shack in which we were locked up and I could swear that some of my comrades had already succumbed to the madness of the desert. They began to hit one another. I kept my distance from them. A few moments later one of my comrades came walking towards me, hopping around in a manner which did not seem all that hostile.

FInally, the barricades keeping us locked in the stone ruins fell down and we all ascended down into the desert. The other officer which did not seem hostile was keen on following me but kept silent.

We wandered the bare and empty desert and in the distance we saw one of our comrades get mauled down by a snake. This was truly a savage place. In the distance we noticed an abandoned village. We decided to scout it for food and water as we were growing thirsty and hungry.

The loud buzzing of a drone filled our surroundings and we noticed a small device with red lights fly past us. Could someone be filming this entire process? Were we merely here for someone's amusement? A few moments later I had discovered a knife. I turned around and beheld my comrade's spine break as his body twisted forwards to grab a vase. He came towards me in a threatening manner.

I had no choice but to cut him down. As his body fell down his neck extended and his limbs began to move in an inhuman manner. I fell down on my knees, madness had infested this place. I heard the footsteps of some of my other silent comrades behind me and I was punched down on the ground, the two silently beat me to death with their fists.

They were Down To One.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Down to One is a brutal battle royal survival game where only one wins. You need eat, drink and kill to win.
I’ll start by saying that this game IS a survival game yes, and yes it IS in early access. I know a lot of people no longer trust the words “early access” and “survival game” when they are put together. But I must admit that this game is good and is only getting better.

Gameplay
The gameplay is good. Getting a kill is really satisfying and is also quite challenging. It really is hard to get the perfect kill and that’s what makes it exiting since some firefights can take a long time and positioning and patients plays a huge part in winning those firefights. Since its early access do expect a LOT of glitches and so on. Although a lot of them don’t really affect you badly and mostly just funny to look at.

Graphics
It is a nice looking game. The guns look unique and so does the map to an extent. I am not really a fan of fancy graphics and I don’t really care about them to be honest but I must admit that the game does look sweet.

The Map/Environment
Since it’s a battle royal you want to make sure the map is interesting with plenty of different key locations. This game does deliver that with quite a few awesome locations like a US military base that spawns the best guns and you also have small villages that spawn lower quality gear but are easier to get to.  The map is also the right size with games not going on for too long. I do hope in the future to see more maps in the game that will be as good as the current one.

Community
The community is very small. That is the biggest drawback of this game.  Games have to be organized because of this at certain times each day. But I must say what community this game does have is a really nice one. The dev is really active listening to what people has to say and also hosts a weekly cup each Friday which is a lot of fun to take part of.

Overall this game is a lot of fun but I only recommend buying it if you are truly ready to support the dev on a very long road and ready to take part in the community to help make this game even better, as it has the potential to do much more and it is already doing a lot as I write this!

Put simply: It's a mess right now. And though I haven't played other games from the genre, I don't think it stands out much from others in its genre.

Positives:
+Extremely cheap to buy (59 cents at the time I bought it and am writing this)
+Perk System

- I'm pretty sure there's nothing here you haven't seen in another game of the genre
- Graphics aren't good (and are glitchy)
- Not optimized well, not at all (I have a 970 graphics card, but can't get anywhere near stable framerate past low settings. Even on low, it feels staggered)
- Glitchy as can be (Climbing a ladder will likely have you INSIDE the ladder, and you won't automatically get off the ladder until you're a few feet above it. There are a few other annoying glitches, but I'd rather keep this short)
- Less than good weapon spawns. You likely won't find a weapon until someone has already shot you with one they were lucky enough to find. I understand that they're supposed to be scarce, but it shouldn't take me 10 minutes just to find a little knife
-Gameplay is rough. I haven't been able to try out a gun yet, but the rest feels like one of the lower quality mods using the Half-Life engine

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the current state of the game, I WOULD highly recommend... But beware, the game is quite dead. In the 4 hours I've played, I played 4 matches.

The matches I DID play were fun, though. There is a very tense atmosphere, as the playing field gets smaller and smaller, and you know there's people who want you dead. Not only do THEY want you did, but there's currently snakes that do too, along with hunger and thirst. The game has somewhat poor performance, but I'm sure that's because my computer isn't exactly the best (High end 2009 laptop). It is also a a bit buggy. My first round was spent under the map, as I fell through it in the waiting area. I've also taken fall damage from stepping off a ladder, though I think that glitch has been fixed.
Overall, once you get INTO a game, I'd give it an 8/10.

tl'dr play it if you're prepared to wait a while for a match.

reviewText:
If you enjoy the Battle Royale style of H1 or other similar games, you should try this out.  It's very early, it doesn't have heavy funding or staffing on the team to get everything worked out right away, but it's a blast.  Even H1, who has plenty of money being thrown at it on a daily basis, has game crippling issues, so don't be so critical with this small timer.

Checkout http://www.twitch.tv/drizzintahl/v/34640202 for a recent stream highlight of the game.

If you haven't played any BR style game like this, here's what to expect.
-Camping
-Waiting
-Patience
-Dieing quickly to something you didn't see or hear after 10-15 minutes of nothing happening.
-Getting punched out early before you get anywhere
-Getting teamed up on in a FFA

Don't expect a fast paced action shooter, this is about getting lucky with item spawns, supply drops, food and water spawns, and knowing the map.  Right now players will clip through walls, rubberband horribly, and meleeing people is very difficult because of the skipping around.

all that aside, I personally love BR gameplay and you can't complain about this price tag.

So I repeat the steps, this time switching it to Fullscreen and it works. But now the Options won't change and the UI keeps disappearing.

So after trying numerous times to fix the issue and end up with the same results. I decided to Issue an apology to the 3 Friends I gifted this game too and sat myself in the naughty corner.

Do not buy this game, unless you're 100% sure it's going to work for you. I mean the price isn't bank braking, but I do feel rather bad for gifting this to people and having it stain there Libraries.

reviewText:
Ok so my time on the game is 0.2 Hours on Record adn most people won't take my review seriously, but hear me out.

The reason my time is so low, is because the game is so buggy, that I spent my time trying to fix one problem for it to be replaced by another. So here's the full story.

I buy the game in the 4 Pack for me and some friends to have a laugh and play against each other. I download and install it, then I get a problem as soon as I load the game up. The mouse doesn't line up with the UI, well that's strange? So I try again in Windowed mode, problem solved. Crappy that I have to play Windowed, but ok I can deal with it. So I decide to change a few settings from the Default. I click an option that creates a drop down box, Oh? It's not working? I click again, this time the drop down menu appears, but the rest of the UI disappears! Now once I choose an option in the box, the WHOLE UI disappears. Now I can't do anything but close the application and start again. Great now the Menus here and the mouse isn't lining up again. So I repeat the steps, this time switching it to Fullscreen and it works. But now the Options won't change and the UI keeps disappearing.

So after trying numerous times to fix the issue and end up with the same results. I decided to Issue an apology to the 3 Friends I gifted this game too and sat myself in the naughty corner.

Do not buy this game, unless you're 100% sure it's going to work for you. I mean the price isn't bank braking, but I do feel rather bad for gifting this to people and having it stain there Libraries.

I feel like i need to write a clear honest review on this game due to all the negative and unhelpful reviews. To start with, the trailer is alot different than the actual game, and this game was 15 dollars in early access. There is no where near the amount of content in this game that it should have with a 15 dollar pricetag. But with release the game is 99 cents and on sale currently 59 cents. I would say there's enough content for 99 cents, but this game is hard to play.

The servers are alright in my opinion, theres definitly some lag spikes but what makes this game hard to play is how you move and the animations. When walking and sprinting you move at a very slow pace and your screen flickers. It's real jumpy and very awquard in how you move. The animations are horrible and often dont match up with what your currently doing. Honestly until they're fixed and look okay, i would rather have no animations at all. Some of the smaller bugs are often hilarious like the dead bodys becoming distorted and girafe-necked.

Another thing i should mention, the servers have been pretty empty. Recently due to the huge price drop and coming out of early access, they're have been alot more players than there was before and now you actually have the chance to play this game with other people, due to the cheap price tag i encourage you to give the game a try and add to the playerbase. There isnt much you can do with 99 cents and if you downright hate it, go to steam help and request a refund.

The only reason im giving this game a thumbs up is because when you look pass all the issues, this game can be entertaining and enjoyable, i think worth the 99 cents. Also the Devs are very active with very frequent updates, i think this game definitly has potential and with the Devs as active as they are, i think they'll fix most of these bugs and the issue with movement.

reviewText:
In short: Good Battle Royale game, has some nice mechanics, but it should not have been released this early.

What happened here:

During the time the game was in early access, the development was exceptional. If you had any issue with the game, the developer would immediately help you out as he could. Any suggestion, criticism, etc, he was there to listen.

The updates were extremely frequent. At first, the focus was on content, from weapons and locations to gamemodes and mechanics, and more recently, the focus shifted towards the bugfixing.

What is perhaps the cause of one of the big problems with this game, is the fact that when in early access, the servers never got to fill up with the serverlist often being completely deserted (people who wanted to play, logged in and upon seeing 0 online players, they naturally closed the game instead of waiting on the lobby area for someone to show up). This situation basically hid many latency/performance problems that would only become apparent on the day of release.
It certainly wasn't for lack of trying though as the developer motivated it as much as he could by organizing and recording weekly tournaments. But still, people (like me) would only show up for the tournaments as that was a time where we were certain that we would be able to play the game (still, they rarely went above 15 players)

Game development is not easy at all. It is an extremely exausting line of work that as the added bonus of producing something potentially subjective to the worst types of criticism. I am not saying that no game is above criticism, but I can assure you that the best efforts were being made here. Whatever reason the developer had to release this game, I am sure that it was a least desired choice that had to be made.

But in the end, when people buy a game, they buy the final product, not the story behind it's conception.

Down to One has been an enjoyable and competent game, but it is extremely buggy, has some game-breaking glitches and (as many report) has some severe performance issues. As difficult as it must have been to keep this game going in early access, releasing it in this state will most likely hurt this game in about a month or two as the playerbase may very well go down again.

I feel like i need to write a clear honest review on this game due to all the negative and unhelpful reviews. To start with, the trailer is alot different than the actual game, and this game was 15 dollars in early access. There is no where near the amount of content in this game that it should have with a 15 dollar pricetag. But with release the game is 99 cents and on sale currently 59 cents. I would say there's enough content for 99 cents, but this game is hard to play.

The servers are alright in my opinion, theres definitly some lag spikes but what makes this game hard to play is how you move and the animations. When walking and sprinting you move at a very slow pace and your screen flickers. It's real jumpy and very awquard in how you move. The animations are horrible and often dont match up with what your currently doing. Honestly until they're fixed and look okay, i would rather have no animations at all. If you can get over these two things, then game plays OK at best.

Next up, the bugs. This game has a few very annoying bugs ive noticed. Sometimes when you pick up items, they dont go to your inventory. Sometimes when you use items, they stick to your weapon after being used. I have glitched through some walls every now and then but thats all that comes to mind at the moment. Some of the smaller bugs are often hilarious like the dead bodys becoming distorted and girafe-necked.

Another thing i should mention, the servers have been pretty empty. Recently due to the huge price drop and coming out of early access, they're have been alot more players than there was before and now you actually have the chance to play this game with other people, due to the cheap price tag i encourage you to give the game a try and add to the playerbase. There isnt much you can do with 99 cents and if you downright hate it, go to steam help and request a refund.

The only reason im giving this game a thumbs up is because when you look pass all the issues, this game can be entertaining and enjoyable, i think worth the 99 cents.
